paragraphs.text: %md ## OML4Py Date and Time Classes Oracle Machine Learning for Python (OML4Py) makes the open source Python scripting language and environment ready for the enterprise and big data. Designed for problems involving both large and small data volumes, OML4Py integrates Python with Oracle Autonomous Database, allowing users to run Python commands and scripts for statistical, machine learning, and visualization analyses on database tables and views using Python syntax. Many familiar Python functions are overloaded that translate Python behavior into SQL for running in-database, as well as new automatic machine learning capabilities. OML4Py provides three classes for manipulating dates and times: `oml.Datetime`, `oml.Timezone`, and `oml.Timedelta`. - `oml.Datetime` represents a table column of dates to support DATE or TIMESTAMP in Oracle Database. - `oml.Timezone` represents a table column of time zone data to support TIMESTAMP WITH TIMEZONE. - `oml.Timedelta` represents a single column of differences between two dates or times to support INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND in Oracle Database. These classes are based on the Python datetime library. In this notebook, we highlight features of OML4Py's date and time functionality. --- Copyright (c) 2023 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
OML4Py Date and Time Classes

Oracle Machine Learning for Python (OML4Py) makes the open source Python scripting language and environment ready for the enterprise and big data. Designed for problems involving both large and small data volumes, OML4Py integrates Python with Oracle Autonomous Database, allowing users to run Python commands and scripts for statistical, machine learning, and visualization analyses on database tables and views using Python syntax. Many familiar Python functions are overloaded that translate Python behavior into SQL for running in-database, as well as new automatic machine learning capabilities.

OML4Py provides three classes for manipulating dates and times: oml.Datetime, oml.Timezone, and oml.Timedelta.

  • oml.Datetime represents a table column of dates to support DATE or TIMESTAMP in Oracle Database.
  • oml.Timezone represents a table column of time zone data to support TIMESTAMP WITH TIMEZONE.
  • oml.Timedelta represents a single column of differences between two dates or times to support INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND in Oracle Database.

These classes are based on the Python datetime library.

In this notebook, we highlight features of OML4Py's date and time functionality.

Copyright (c) 2023 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.title: Import libraries
paragraphs.text:
%python

import oml

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

import datetime
from datetime import datetime, timezone, timedelta

paragraphs.title: View schema of SH.SALES table, which contains a DATE column TIME_ID
paragraphs.text:
%script

describe SH.SALES

msg.data:
Name          Null?    Type         
------------- -------- ------------ 
PROD_ID NOT NULL NUMBER 
CUST_ID NOT NULL NUMBER 
TIME_ID  NOT NULL DATE     
CHANNEL_ID NOT NULL NUMBER 
PROMO_ID NOT NULL NUMBER 
QUANTITY_SOLD NOT NULL NUMBER(10,2) 
AMOUNT_SOLD NOT NULL NUMBER(10,2) 

---------------------------

paragraphs.title: Create a proxy object from a table with DATE columns
paragraphs.text:
%python

SALES = oml.sync(schema="SH", table="SALES")
z.show(SALES.head())

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Compute statistics on table columns
paragraphs.text:
%python

pd.set_option('display.max_columns', 50)
pd.set_option('display.width', 1000)

SALES.describe(include='all')

paragraphs.title: Compute statistics on DATE column TIME_ID
paragraphs.text:
%python

SALES['TIME_ID'].describe()

msg.data:
count                  918843
unique                   1460
top       2001-10-18 00:00:00
freq                     2940
Name: TIME_ID, dtype: object

paragraphs.title: Extract date-related features
paragraphs.text:
%python

date = SALES['TIME_ID']
SALES2 = SALES.concat({'YEAR': date.year, 'MONTH': date.month})
SALES2.head()

%md
## oml.Datetime

To create a date in Python, we use the `datetime` class of the `datetime` module, which is included in Python. The `datetime` class requires three parameters: *year*, *month*, and *day*. It also contains optional parameters for time and timezone, including *hour*, *minute*, *second*, *microsecond*, and *tzone*.

Create a datetime object with the year, month, and day, then create a temporary proxy object using `oml.push`. The `oml.push `function requires a data frame or list as input, so we first convert the date object to a list. The resulting object is an object of class `oml.Datetime`.

msg.data:
oml.Datetime

To create a date in Python, we use the datetime class of the datetime module, which is included in Python. The datetime class requires three parameters: year, month, and day. It also contains optional parameters for time and timezone, including hour, minute, second, microsecond, and tzone.

Create a datetime object with the year, month, and day, then create a temporary proxy object using oml.push. The oml.pushfunction requires a data frame or list as input, so we first convert the date object to a list. The resulting object is an object of class oml.Datetime.

paragraphs.title: datetime
paragraphs.text:
%python

d1 = datetime(year=2004, month=7, day=24)

print('d1:', d1)
print('type:', type(d1))
print('year:', d1.year)
print('month:', d1.month)
print('day:', d1.day)

paragraphs.title: oml.Datetime
paragraphs.text:
%python

d1_lst = [d1] 
D1 = oml.push(d1_lst)

print('D1:   ', D1)
print('type: ', type(D1))
print('year: ', D1.year)
print('month:', D1.month)
print('day:  ', D1.day)

%md
---

The datetime method `fromisoformat` constructs a date or datetime object from a string containing date in ISO format, e.g., yyyy-mm-dd. Create a datetime object with the year, month, day, and time, then create a temporary proxy object using `oml.push`. The resulting object is an object of class `oml.Datetime`.

msg.data: The datetime method fromisoformat constructs a date or datetime object from a string containing date in ISO format, e.g., yyyy-mm-dd. Create a datetime object with the year, month, day, and time, then create a temporary proxy object using oml.push. The resulting object is an object of class oml.Datetime.

paragraphs.text:
%python

d2 = datetime.fromisoformat('2004-07-24 00:05:23+04:00')
d2_lst=[d2]

D2 = oml.push(d2_lst)

print('D2', D2)
print('type', type(D2))

%python

datetime.now()

%md --- The `strftime` method converts a datetime object to a string, and `strptime` converts a string to a datetime object. Dates have a default representation of: **YYYY-MM-DD:HH:MM:SS.mmmmmm** but you may want to print them in a specific format. In that case, you can get a custom string representation using the available format codes. The format codes for the default date representation are shown in the table below.
Code Example Description
%a Sun Day abbreviated
%b Sep Month abbreviated
%d 08 Decimal Month
%H 07 Decimal Hour
%M 06 Decimal Minute
%S 05 Decimal Second
%Y 2015 Decimal Year

msg.data:
The strftime method converts a datetime object to a string, and strptime converts a string to a datetime object. Dates have a default representation of: YYYY-MM-DD:HH:MM:SS.mmmmmm
but you may want to print them in a specific format. In that case, you can get a custom string representation using the available format codes.

The format codes for the default date representation are shown in the table below.

Code Example Description
%a Sun Day abbreviated
%b Sep Month abbreviated
%d 08 Decimal Month
%H 07 Decimal Hour
%M 06 Decimal Minute
%S 05 Decimal Second
%Y 2015 Decimal Year

paragraphs.title: Convert date to string
paragraphs.text:
%python

D3 = D2.strftime()

print('D3', D3)
print('type', type(D3))

paragraphs.title: Convert string to date
paragraphs.text:
%python

d4 = "14-Jul-05 20:01:01"
d4_lst = [d4]

# create a temporary proxy object
D4 = oml.push(d4_lst)

# convert the string to an oml.Datetime object with the provided format
D5 = oml.Datetime.strptime(D4, format="DD-Mon-RR HH24:MI:SS")

print('D5', D5)
print('type', type(D5))

%md
## oml.Timedelta

`oml.Timedelta` objects represent a column of differences between two dates or times and can be used to perform simple arithmetic operations on `oml.Datetime` objects. `oml.Timedelta` objects can be multiplied by an integer value or a floating point value. Subtracting dates produces an `oml.Timedelta` object that can be added or subtracted by an `oml.Timedate` object to produce another date.

msg.data:
oml.Timedelta

oml.Timedelta objects represent a column of differences between two dates or times and can be used to perform simple arithmetic operations on oml.Datetime objects. oml.Timedelta objects can be multiplied by an integer value or a floating point value. Subtracting dates produces an oml.Timedelta object that can be added or subtracted by an oml.Timedate object to produce another date.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a time-based object using the current date and time, and create an `oml.Timedelta` object named DELT1 to determine a past and future dates.

msg.data: Create a time-based object using the current date and time, and create an oml.Timedelta object named DELT1 to determine a past and future dates.

paragraphs.title: timedelta
paragraphs.text:
%python

today = datetime.now()
print('today:', today)

delt1 = timedelta(days=1, hours=2, seconds=5)
print('delt1:', delt1)
print('type:', type(delt1))

paragraphs.title: oml.Timedelta
paragraphs.text:
%python

dat = pd.DataFrame({'datetime': [today], 'timedelta': [delt1]})

DAT = oml.push(dat, dbtypes = ['TIMESTAMP', 'INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND'])
print(DAT)

TODAY = DAT['datetime']
DELT1 = DAT['timedelta']

print('TODAY:', today)
print('DELT1:', DELT1)
print('type:', type(DELT1))

msg.data:
datetime       timedelta
0 2023-05-31 20:00:38.154038 1 days 02:00:05
TODAY: 2023-05-31 20:00:38.154038
DELT1: [datetime.timedelta(days=1, seconds=7205)]
type: <class 'oml.core.timedelta.Timedelta'>

paragraphs.title: timedelta operations
paragraphs.text:
%python

past_date1 = today - delt1
print('past date 1:', past_date1)

past_date2 = today - (delt1 *3)
print('past date 2:', past_date2)

future_date1 = today + delt1
print('future date 1:', future_date1)

future_date2 = today + (delt1 *3)
print('future date 2:', future_date2)

paragraphs.title: oml.Timedelta operations
paragraphs.text:
%python

past_date3 = TODAY - DELT1
print('past date 3:', past_date1)

past_date4 = TODAY - (DELT1 *3)
print('past date 4:', past_date2)

future_date3 = TODAY + DELT1
print('future date 3:', future_date1)

future_date4 = TODAY + (DELT1 *3)
print('future date 4:', future_date2)

%md
## Value Comparison

Dates and datetime objects can be compared using standard arithmetic comparison operators (like <, >, <=, >=, != etc.). 

The examples below compare `oml.Datetime` columns in a proxy object.

msg.data:
Value Comparison

Dates and datetime objects can be compared using standard arithmetic comparison operators (like <, >, <=, >=, != etc.).

The examples below compare oml.Datetime columns in a proxy object.

paragraphs.title: Create Proxy data frame with two oml.Datetime columns
paragraphs.text:
%python

d1 = datetime(2005, 7, 14, 5, 10, 30)
d2 = datetime(2004, 6, 30, 1, 22, 46)
d3 = datetime(2003, 12, 10, 12, 50, 25)
d4 = datetime(2002, 3, 20, 20, 42, 59)

d3 = pd.DataFrame({'X': [d1, d2], 'Y': [d3, d4]})                                                              
D3 = oml.push(d3, dbtypes = ['TIMESTAMP', 'TIMESTAMP'])

print(D3)

%python

D4 = D3['X']
D5 = D3['Y']

print("D4:", D4)
print("D4 type:", type(D4))

print("D5:", D5)
print("D5 type:", type(D5))

msg.data:
D4: [datetime.datetime(2005, 7, 14, 5, 10, 30), datetime.datetime(2004, 6, 30, 1, 22, 46)]
D4 type: <class 'oml.core.datetime.Datetime'>
D5: [datetime.datetime(2003, 12, 10, 12, 50, 25), datetime.datetime(2002, 3, 20, 20, 42, 59)]
D5 type: <class 'oml.core.datetime.Datetime'>

paragraphs.title: equal to
paragraphs.text:
%python

# equal to
print(D4 == D5)

# not equal to
print(D4 != D5)

paragraphs.title: greater than
paragraphs.text:
%python

# greater than
print(D4 > D5) 

# greater than or equal to
print(D4 >= D5) ##

paragraphs.title: less than
paragraphs.text:
%python

# less than
print(D4 < D5)

# less than or equal to
print(D4 <= D5)

paragraphs.title: max/min
paragraphs.text:
%python

print("max:", D3['X'].max())

print("min:", D3['Y'].min())

%md
## Value Replacement

Update specific or all elements of an `oml.Datetime` object, such as year, month, and day.

msg.data:
Value Replacement

Update specific or all elements of an oml.Datetime object, such as year, month, and day.

paragraphs.text:
%python

D4 = D3['X'].replace(year=2000)
print("D4:", D4)

D5 = D3['X'].replace(month=11)
print("D5:", D5)

D6 = D3['X'].replace(day=6)
print("D6:", D6)

msg.data:
D4: [datetime.datetime(2000, 7, 14, 5, 10, 30), datetime.datetime(2000, 6, 30, 1, 22, 46)]
D5: [datetime.datetime(2005, 11, 14, 5, 10, 30), datetime.datetime(2004, 11, 30, 1, 22, 46)]
D6: [datetime.datetime(2005, 7, 6, 5, 10, 30), datetime.datetime(2004, 6, 6, 1, 22, 46)]

paragraphs.text:
%md
---
## Date Exploration

Create an OML proxy object containing a datetime column and explore the object using the transparency layer functions `describe`, `nunique`, `min` and `max`.

msg.data:
Date Exploration

Create an OML proxy object containing a datetime column and explore the object using the transparency layer functions describe, nunique, min and max.

paragraphs.text:
%python

date_today = datetime.now()
ndays = 10

df = pd.DataFrame({'Date': [date_today + timedelta(days=x) for x in range(ndays)], 
                   'Val': pd.Series(np.random.randn(ndays))})

DF = oml.push(df)
DF.head()

paragraphs.title: describe date column
paragraphs.text:
%python

DF['Date'].describe()

msg.data:
count                             10
unique                            10
top       2023-06-09 20:00:42.184050
freq                               1
Name: Date, dtype: object

paragraphs.title: number of unique dates
paragraphs.text:
%python

DF['Date'].nunique()

paragraphs.title: earliest date
paragraphs.text:
%python

DF['Date'].min()

paragraphs.title: latest date
paragraphs.text:
%python

DF['Date'].max()

%md
---

Explore the `sort_values`, `head`, and  `tail` functions by sorting values by Date in ascending and descending order.

msg.data: Explore the sort_values, head, and tail functions by sorting values by Date in ascending and descending order.

paragraphs.title: ascending order - first five rows
paragraphs.text:
%python

DF.sort_values(by = ['Date'], ascending=False).head(5)

paragraphs.title: descending order - last 5 rows
paragraphs.text:
%python

DF.sort_values(by = ['Date'], ascending=False).tail(5)

%md
